Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Epiaortic Ultrasound in Surgical Aortic Valve Replacement

Trial_Design.evidence: In a randomised controlled trial, SAVR patients were assigned to two embolic protection devices.

Intervention.evidence: SAVR patients were assigned to two embolic protection devices.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Multivariable logistic regression estimated associations between atheroma grade and adverse outcomes, including death, stroke, cerebral infarction on DW-MRI, delirium, and acute kidney injury (AKI) by 7 and 30 days.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Of 383 randomised patients, 326 (85.1%) had pre-cannulation epiaortic ultrasound data.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of 383 randomised patients, 326 (85.1%) had pre-cannulation epiaortic ultrasound data.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Moderate/severe atheroma grade was associated with a greater risk of AKI by 7 days (adjusted OR: 2.63; 95% CI: 1.24–5.58; p=0.01). At 30 days, these patients had a greater risk of death, stroke, or AKI (adjusted OR: 1.97; 95% CI: 1.04–3.71; p=0.04).

Harms.evidence: Moderate/severe atheroma grade was associated with a greater risk of AKI by 7 days (adjusted OR: 2.63; 95% CI: 1.24–5.58; p=0.01).
